element_texts.text: Completed

letterhead  LAWRENCE HILL & CO. PUBLISHERS, INC.  150 5TH AVENUE NEW YORK, NEW YORK  10011  PHONE  741-3838
July 30, 1974
Dear Jack: -

   I just realized I had not heard directly from "the Sage" for some time.  Just received from Jack Salzman a collection of Conroyana & a ms from Helen Bugbee sent at your suggestion.  How are you & did you ever make that trip to the Coast?  Is there anything you can do to rescue  Stefan Heym's wonderful book underlined:  The Queen Against Defoe from oblivion?  His book & his comments on the position of the writer under Socialism has been completely ignored while reams of type has been devoted to that mystic reactionary Solzhenitsyn.

Regards, Larry
Enclosing an item for your collection.
Completed

10/14/74
Dear Jack,

  Vacation, and house guests - so all kinds of stuff got inaccessible, including "Charley was our darlin" - which I enjoyed so much - buried under dumped mail, magazines, and such.
   When will the book be out, Jack?  I'm only one of many who are eager to hold it in our hands at last.  Meantime, I appreciate the chapter 2 reprint.
    Irene Ferguson is doing nicely after a hysterectomy last week.
   Looks like the end of the road very soon at New Standard for us elderly.  The set will coast along with no extensive revision.
   Ruth and I send  you and Gladys best wishes.

Sincerely,
Harry
Completed

11/29/74
Dear Jack

   Was glad to see another review by you - had missed them for awhile.
    Enjoyed reading your Bontemps memories in underlined:  American Libraries - excellent.  Others in the office are seeing it too.
    My stay at Standard has another month.  Am starting to look for a replacement (job).
    Ruth joins me in wishing you and Gladys the very best.

Harry
Completed

in pencil in left margin   [1981]   Rosler, Alice
greeting  card  May the Serenity of the Season Last Throughout Your Year   BIRDS IN LANDSCAPE  Japanese two panel screen.  Edo period, early 17th century.  Hasegawa school by Hasegawa Tojin (Tonin).  Freer Gallery of Art   Smithsonian Institution Washington, D.C. (62.11)  WXC=13209  PRINTED IN SWITZERLAND FOR H. GEORGE CASPARI, INC.

Dear Jack and Gladys:

    Because of ill health Louis Ewing retires as president at the end of the year.  His son Peter will succeed him in the title, while his father will stay on as a consultant.  The young man is the middle son, a Viet Nam veteran and a nice guy.  
    Of course, one has to be a member of the family to assume such a position at his age.
    Some months ago, Geraldine, Grace Vanderbilt's successor dropped in for a visit.  Her old friends did not even recognize her.  She hardly knew anyone on the staff.   Ralph Miller moved into a hotel.
    Best wishes for your health and happiness.   Alice
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Roth, Jules
March 9, 1980
Dear Jack:

     Its been a while since we have last written to each other, but I have a special reason for writing, which I will go into shortly.  But first, tell me about how your health is, and that of your wife.  My health isn't bad, really, for a 68-year-old.
     Last night, my wife and I went to the Apollo Theatre on Lincoln Ave., to see the "Banjo Dancer."  This is a one-man performance, where Stephen Wade plays the Banjo very expertly, and also relates stories and anecdotes in a real folksy manner.   He has received rave notices for the excellance [sic] of his performance, having been on for maybe eight months.  Steve is only twenty-seven years old, but has the polish of a much older person.
     One  of the stories he told was about a competition between two professional high-divers.   Each time, they raise the height level from which they dive, and reduce the depth of the water they dive into.  After the conclusion of the story, he mentioned that he read it in a Writers Project publication and that it was written by Jack Conroy, who lives in Moberly, Mo.!  I was so
Completed

2
excited by this information, I wanted to jump up and shout, "I know Jack Conroy!"

    You can see, this young fellow has class.   After each story he related, he was sure to mention the source of his information.   I hope that things are reasonably well for you, and yours.  Wade mentioned that you were eighty years old, but I'm sure that is wrong.  By the way, the next time you come in to Chicago, think about calling me up?  I could then call Gordon Crandall.  My phone number is:  539 6589, and I can be reached in the evening.
  Chicago weather this year has been far more moderate than last year's, but we are getting a little belated winter weather, in the middle of March.
   I hope I hear from you, in reply, in the near future?

Cordially yours,
Jules Roth
Completed

in pencil in top margin   Roth, Jules
April 14, 1980
Dear Jack:

   I am replying to your fine letter of March 22.   I, too, was impressed by the personality and quality of Stephen Wade's performance.  So talented, and so young!  I was surprised (but delighted) that he could dispense with such handsome royalties, especially since he gave credit to maybe six or eight other sources for the stories he told.  Such generous royalties must have set him back, quite a bit.
   Instead of seeing the reviews in the papers about the Jack Conroy Reader, I heard one on "Critic's Choice," WFMT, by Herman Kogan.  He spent the whole half-hour one Sunday, discussing the book and your writings.  I was very gratified to hear it.  The enclosed clipping was sent to me by Gordon Crandall, from the Tribune.  Maybe it is the same review you mention in your letter, as of March 16.
   I am sorry that you do not have occasional book reviews appearing in the Sun-Times.  Or is it because I don't read the Sunday papers any more?   Its too time-consuming, and I have loads of other reading material to attend to.
   Do you have any compensation to look forward to if they Reader finally gets published?  I hope so.
   Another Project round-up doesn't
Completed

2
seem likely, as of now.  But who knows, maybe in someone's febrile brain, such a [sic] enterprise is germinating.  I would certainly welcome it.

    Jack, how is your health?  Do you have a chance to enjoy the outdoor environment near you?  What is it like -- hilly, woodsy -- near Moberly?
    When the book is finally published, if you think of it, send me a reminder, and Ill [sic] get me a copy, at Kroch's, or whatever.
    Meanwhile, continued good health, a continued enchantment with the good things of life, your friend,     Jules
Completed

back of greeting card
Best to Douglas Wexton and anyone else near you -  Love Chris & ?Nel?
Completed

inside of greeting card
Dear Jack

  Wish we were there at the reception.  That Wexon is sure doing you justice that you well deserved - may underlined:  THE WEED KING restore your fame.
   Enjoyed the review by Jeff Truesdale of the Tribune, another fan on your side
   I've  been promoting this new book and [[underlined:  DisenHerited [sic] ]] among the profs here at Western New Mexico University every chance I get
   Douglas tells me you got a New eyeball to read this with; but I'll let Chris finish this letter she writes more legebly [sic] than I   Best of luck and health my dear old Sage! 

and now for me -- this photo of Sarah reminds
caption at bottom of card  Sarah Bernhardt  The Divine Sarah   1844-1923
Completed

inside of greeting card
me of Theodora and I wish I had the drama of Sarah -- how are you?  and we wish we could be with you on November 2 - but we haven't been anywhere for years & years.  Amanda & Bettina Drew are coming for visit around Nov 20 and we'll call you on the phone so you can talk with them.  Also going to send Meridel's address in Arizona - there for the winter -
Completed

in pencil at top of page  Rowland, Chris
back of a greeting card
Dear Jack
Now you know you've always been the one!  Yours forever Chris R  The Duchess
HANG THIS on your wall & everyone will know the truth
Completed

in pencil in top margin  [no date]  Rowland, Chris
3
Kup wrote in his column he was sitting in front row of Mencky's Burlesque new show that opened at Edgewater Beach - reviews all panned it poor old Awg - he better get on a farm, stay there & work - get his health back & forget about writing for a while - he'll end up like Bodenheim -

  Rosie might be out of hospital by the time you get here but I don't know - in any case we may not have the greatest party going but we want to see you without a whole bunch of people around so we can hear about the 2 trips of Europe - and bring pictures of your house in Moberly - did you ever get my note at your old house in Chicago?  the number at home is 219-938-1781  written under 219 ar code from Chgo
Completed

Neal is home on Mon & Thur because he has classes those days.  Tues, Wed, Fri in Chicago working on designs for film lab - far north -
Write & say where, when, you'll be coming in ? etc
Chris
Best regards & love to Gladys & you must have become a great houskeeper [sic]  since her accident.
Completed

front and back of greeting card
IMAGE on front of card:  pansies Congratulations
making a speech and it was wonderful!  hope that Studs was at the Drake (if he was in town) wrote Meridel today about you & sending Amanda & Bettina notes also - B is still working on bio she says in last letter - Neal is writing you a note too Love from both of us   Neal & Chris
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Rowland, Neal & Chris
greeting card  Since I cannot bring you congratulations face to face may these flowers speak to you and do it in my place...
Dear Jack  We've read your letter to everyone around:  McCoo, Martha, her daughter and May Stevens here for visit from NY and all thrilled about the underlined:  award and even some recent friends heard about the 50th year of underlined:  The Disinherited and the Japanese edition - They were amazed - and are going to read the book in English - woman a librarian and was impressed that it was in print after  50 years -  Wexon did a fine job on the presentation - wish they had made a video on it - saw a video of Meridel
Completed

This little gift is from Mexico - across from ElPaso - Juarez and we want you to feel better -- they say this figure on necklace brings good health for those who wear it - Big floods here -- no mail going out for days - no power for 24 hrs - no phones - were isolated but love it -- Come when you can -  Neal & Chris - This is our Xmas card
Completed

in pencil in top margin Rowland, Chris & Neal
Dear Jack:  Everyone has seen the poster since it is hanging over the dining room wall and all marvel at your great good looks - and newsletter all read - also have New Letters with all stories & etc about you & everyone impressed with your pics & writings - Knew about Fallon but not about Finch - never thought he'd go but maybe over becoming a born again Christian - good news about Dottie having a fortune - has she been to see you or given up any of the loot to you or some of it?  here's a Eternal Life that you may send to anyone who needs to read it - do you know Barbara A Dwyer? Been all involved with hearings about Bark & glad he was tossed to the winds; and then Douglas who was a dope & admitted smoking that weed and now hope that Kennedy gets dumped too - what we need is another woman on the court or a Hispanic or another black - when I think of that confederacy of dunces around underlined: raygun it makes my liver quiver - such louts!  and now the Persian Gulf caper - Meese is one of the idiots who has to be replaced - he just sits up there lies like a pro.  Write me & give opinions of the current situation.   Chris & Neal
Completed

postcard letterhead  Neal and Chris Rowland  5924 Birch Avenue  Miller Beach, Gary, Indiana
Dear One Your most wonderful gift was a thing of joy and Bless you, boy, for thinking of this lost soul out here in the wilds of the Dunes - keep next Monday the 14th open on acct of we might get ? for a small but elegant party and the eats are supposed to be splendid - will call you during the week for confirmation or maybe someone will call you - anyway you are a most fervent friend of my sister Ann     
Chris
Completed

postcard
postmark  LAWRENCE KS  66044  JUL 14 PM  1971

The Conroy Place
701 Fisk
Moberly, Missouri
Dear Jack,

 This is Picture of me at work this Summer - All Calm and Steely-eyed.  Gwen, Girls and I still enjoying pleasant thoughts of last weekend's visit.  Thanks again so much for the J.W.D. and good company.
    There is much rain here, much heat, and no money to fix air-conditioners.   Latest AAUP report shows KU on bottom of wage scale for Universities it's [sic] size.  Only the football team got pay raises this year -   Chris -
Completed

8 Sep 71
Dear Jack,

  Got your good Card - hope you like this volume -
  I know of the Aydelotte letter - he, David Heron (Director of All Libraries here), Ed Grier (20th C. Am. Lit), John Willingham (just finishing book on Waldo Frank) are all interested, as well as me.  I'm trying to keep abreast of the situation.  If I can help in any way let me know -
  More Later - Time to go to Work ----- Chris
Completed

in pencil in top margin  [1972]
clipping pasted on page
NATURE BOY
By Eden Ahbez
There was a boy,
A very strange, enchanted boy; 
They say he wandered very far, very far
Over land and sea.
A little shy and sad of eye,
But very wise was he.
And then one day,
A magic day, he passed my way
And while we spoke of many things, fools and kings,
This he said to me:
"The greatest thing you'll ever learn
Is just to love and be loved in return."

Dear Jack & Gladys
loved your letter going to subscribe to the magazine you sent - would love to have h ad the issue with Wright in it - however will see it when next  we visit you on next trip out -  Neal is coming after Xmas so he'll stop by - in the meantime take it easy but take it
Chris
Completed

17 Feb 72
Jack -

   Your card arrived today.   I have planned to see Fabre here Friday, 25 Feb., at least twice.  Now that I know you will be in K.C., I'll probably come in to say 'howdy.'  Have you thought about coming out to spend a day or so?
   Our library has not received an underlined:  American Book Collector since the Nov-Dec 71 issue.  Trouble with the distributor in Topeka.  KU has no underlined:  December past   1964 or 65  But I get hold of underlined:  NewLetters.   Can you get me a copy of underlined:  December?
  Reading your piece in underlined:  NL, it struck me that you're the only man I know
Completed

who writes exactly like he talks.  I can hear you when I read the words.

   Gwen, girls, Joshua fine after a bout with the flu - Gwen wants to come in Wed. to see you, too, so if we solve babysitter problems we'll be there somewhere.
   Say "Hi" to Madam Queen for us.

Chris
Completed

in pencil in top margin   [1972]

postmark  LAWRENCE KS  ? M  MAY 8 1972  55044

Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave
Moberly, MO.  65270
Jack - Culture heroes for a Kultchur hero - Saw the review at KU Library.  Many thanks.  Am sending off for my own copy.  My Ph.D. oral exams are in one month - after that - the dissertation.  Hope to be allowed to mine your collection and/or correspondence - Children all well - Joshua spoiled. --  Chris
Completed

Chris Rowland, circa 9-15-'74
cartoon of seven figures, three men and four women with conversation bubbles above
When speaking about people who are talkative why are men called articulate and women Gabby?
Why are angry men called outraged while angry women are called hysterical?  
Why is it that men of ordinary appearance are called pleasant-looking when ordinary women are called homely?
Why are careful men called prudent but the same kind of woman is called obsessive?
Why are men who are forgetful called agsent-minded [sic] when forgetful women are known as scatterbrained?
Why are men who are efficient referred to as competent but efficient women are compulsive?
Why are devious men considered shrews when devious women are scheming?  Why are women who are dauntless considered brazen when dauntless men are considered fearless?
In speaking about a person who is industrious why are women called drudges when men are known as hard workers?
Why are light-hearted men called easygoing but the same type of women are called frivolous?
Why are women who are thoughtful called considerate While such men are called over-sensitive?
Why is it that when men talk together it is called conversation but when women talk with each other it is called gossip?
Why are men who are interested  in everything referred to as curious but such women are nosy?
Dear Jack.   Read Am's letter & please respond and ask for some ?fade? - I hope you can give her some info - read your article about Anvil - simply wonderful - going to send for Bowling Green direct - Peypi is still good  -- Nixon
Completed

and his antics have left me weak - he's going to beat the rap yet - of course he's dying with fury since he lost his crown & is no longer king - still I want to see him languish in jail for a while - can't forgive him for Helen G Douglas, Voorhis & Hiss   Chris -- how is Gladys?  did Neal bring your present?
Completed

11-14-74
Dear Jack Sage of Moberly

  Your pornographic picture with the girl wrapping her 4 unclear words tree arrived.  "By God, I bet he could have."
   How are you and Madam ? ?  When I arrived home last August Bob Mac Cullough was here ( ? inland ? nearby)  He asked me who wrote the aphorism on the side of my refrigerator.  I asked "what aphorism?"  "And I looked.  Sure enough in a drunken moment of sheer truth I had scribbled and forgotten months before:  "Nielson A. Green:  the Nixon of Proletarian writers"
    I must have been drunk.  I don't see things that clearly when I'm sober.
    But Chris does.  She was watching TV yesterday and pointed to Yasar Arafat on the screen and said:  "That looks like Nielson!"   Same eyes and bags under, and same jowls.  I looked and sure sure enough.
  Do you suppose when he left the ? Puerto Rican triangle without leaving a forwarding address he went to the United Nations as surrogate Palistinian leader/terrorist?
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Rowland, Neal
postal card
8/19/76
[Gibby Gilbert & wife plan to be  our neighbors in '77   When the Conroys at Rowlands Folly?
Dear Jack & Gladys

   Just got your card today.  Sorry to hear about Margaret Jean.  My sincerest condolence.  When last I saw her,  it was a small Kidney ?, but serious she said.
   The reason I haven't stopped by to see you "friends of man" is some problems.  Flew Daryn here last December to rescue Kathie, who was embroiled in border war, & then flew back - and am still paying for it.  she drove the big truck up in May; we loaded it up heavy and drove back by short cuts avoiding mountains etc.  Last Wednesday 5 hrs   drive back with Uncle Tom Metdopolis to pick up my car while I guard the border.  Plan to drive big truck back in Oct for another load    Plan to ? your hospitality ?     Neal
Completed

Drawing of cat reading a book with title "Joy to the World.." with church in background and five other animals and birds around the cat
12-18-85  Gila, N.M
Dear Jack,

  Congratulations on the new book.  some of the stories I had never read.
   Read them all, new and old, with new pleasure
   Wixon did a good job.
   So underlined:  eat, don't underlined: drink or smoke, and keep your Irish up.
   With deep affection,

Neal & Chris
Duke and Duchess of Hell's Half Acre, New Mexico
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Rowland, Neal & Chris
letterhead with drawing of a cow   This is No Bull!
12-23-'86
Dear Jack,

     Inclosed a book to keep you busy next year.
     Thanks for the Ben Reitman book review.  Some of our best friends were quite fond of him.  
     You were so right about the spiteful titles of my last two "romps."  underlined:  American History sent them back underlined:  unread the next day with a 3 page printout of what is acceptable for their elete [sic] pages.
     Plan to change the story about the Capture of Bach's home town to:   underlined:  THE EISENACH CONCERTO
Completed

And send it elsewhere.

    underlined:  American History also apprised me that their pages are so precious that  they only accept articles of 3,200 words or less.
    My typewriter, of course, runs off at the mouth like my pen.
    also inclosed:  Georgie Shaw on Christmas
    Say hello to Doug Wilson and Susanne
    Again, Have another year of glory.

In haste
Neal & Chris
Completed

in pencil at top of page  Jan 27, 1987
Dear Jack - your note on your Christmas has been heeded and we've all made toasts to  you including Amanda Algren who was here for a week looking at houses because she wants to move here - just left for LA but gave me these photos of crossed out:  Margie  Mary Ellen Sullivan & other friends - if you can make out who they are - good - and you
Completed

can send them to Harold Sullivan if you want - by the way here are 2 more messages from Tom Creswell & Allan Covici from their cards that you might enjoy - sending all underlined: 3 out to friends - see enclosure - hope you don't mind that you might get a note or two from sadder friends - we were all talking about old friends and wondering what
Completed

3
happened to many of them - like what happened to Finch & where does he live if still with us - we know that Fallon died but when?  Did it happen in Florida?  Where is Dorothy Farrell?  in Chicago?  When you have time answer re:  Fallon, Finch - heard from a woman named Deirdra Bair who is writing book on Simone de Beauvoir - met
Completed

her in Paris 1981 - and was going to interview Nelson - but he died day before they were going to have interview & now what [sic] to talk with us - has she written you?  lives at 1020 W Upsal St. Philadelphia Pa  19119  -- Bettina Drew gave her info - but don't think they know each other --  Wixsom sent great card & letter full of ?'s & must write him next - if you see or hear from him tell him am sorry about delay -
Your devoted friend
Chris
Completed

in pencil in top margin Rowland, Neal & Chris  [1988]
greeting card  You'll have your old BOUNCE back in NO time!   GET WELL SOON
Dear Jack  So glad you're feeling better & wish you were here to tell stories to our son Stevie & his son Robert Neal who are here for about 27 days away from the cold in Wisconsin - it's been in the 60's lately and the kid can't get over the heat wave after 5 inches of snow in Wisconsin - wish we could see you for a long visit!  Love Neal & Chris
Completed

gave her your address & hope you hear soon; from a note from Ida & Studs they are thinking of you too and wishing for your full recovery as we are --
your devoted underlined: friends  Neal & Chris
Granta Magazine 23, Spring 88 has essay on J. D. Salinger - very good!

in pencil in top margin  Rowland, Neal & Chris [1988]
greeting card  Sending this cheerful message To say "Hello" and then -- Hope it won't be very long Until you're well again!
Dear Jack - McCullough called this morning wanting news of you - said note he sent to Moberly was returned - sent him your address today so you'll be hearing from him - also Tom Creswell who you met briefly sends his best regards - he was English Prof at City College in Chgo - McCullough remarried 6 years ago - artist from Norway & going to school to become teacher for Special Ed kids - Amanda moved out here 10 days ago & getting settled with 2 dogs & 1 cat named Nelson - she sends her best wishes - drove out from Calif with Bettina Drew (writing book on Nelon [sic] remember her?
Completed

  Haven't had a report from that good guy Wixson lately.  I guess he's pretty busy.

Neal & Chris

Dear Jack,

  Doug Wixon tells us you're coming back strong.  Keep it up.  We went you underlined: three notes earlier to the Hospital.  Hope they catch up to you.  dout is a real friend he keeps us informed step by step.
   I was just about to send him a couple of stories for him to pass on to you.
   Now I hear you're reading newspapers again.

different handwriting
And we want to really consider coming for a visit after Amanda moves down here -
Chris & Neal

in pencil in top margin  Rowland, Chris  [1989/90]
greeting card  SINCERELY WISHING THAT YOU WILL SOON BE UP AND WELL!
Dear Jack,

   We hear you're doing fine.  Keep it up.
    Have you heard all the news about "STUDS" out of Chicago?  He's also going to be in a movie EIGHT MEN OUT about the underlined: White Sox scandal?  We hear.
    Up here on Rancho Rolando our daughter and husband are going into the second year building heir "Dome House" (geodesic).  Our help is limited because of our "years."

Love, Neal & Chris
heard from Bettina Drew who says she has to have the book ready for publisher by the first of year but doesn't think

in pencil in top margin  Rowland, Neal & Chris  [1989/90]
Answered
Dear Jack

    How are you?  Getting around a bit I hope -  Wixon was in Chgo recently and hope he talked with Meridel who was also there at a conference - got all this news from a letter of Charlotte Koch - am writing Meridel after this note & sending her the same stuff in envelope - the
Completed

Cgo Tribune except from bio of Nelson by Bettina - didn't know if you got copy - cousin of mine sent it - also Wilderness Outlook local free paper put out by fellow from crossed out:  N.J Boston who has been in the area couple years and loves it  - Bettina is in another article cousin just sent but haven't read it yet - Doug Wixon probably gets all this stuff too - say hello for us & love to you from Neal & Chris

  Stay well and maybe we'll get together soon.

Love from Neal & Chris

in pencil in top margin  [1989/90]  Rowland, Neal & Chris
greeting card   Thinking of you as I always do and hoping you're feeling much better.
Dear Jack    Still thinking of seeing you in Gila where you 'll be able to see Martha Gilbert, Amanda Algren and us of course - if one of your grandsons gets a motor home or big car or what they call a small van, he and friends can drive you here - Meridel says she is coming too - wants to see her brother in Tuscon & see the Indian dances -  Saw a wonderful hour and a half about James Baldwin on PBS last night - wish I could get film of it but don't think it is possible - going to write underlined:  American Masters at PBS local station
Completed

postcard  CAESAREA - ANCIENT ROMAN AMPHITHEATRE  REBUILT AFTER AN INTERVAL OF 2000 YEARS
postmark  JERUSALEM  8.3.9  V  writing in Hebrew and Arabic
double underline:  Airmail
Mr & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo.  65270  U.S.A.
3/7/69
Dear Jack & Gladys,
I never dreamed I'd ever go overseas, but here I am in underlined:  Israel and from there we are going to Athens & Lisbon & then home after 3 Jampacked weeks of touring - Love it but am ready to come home after 2 weeks  I'm so tired.  Beautiful country.  Hope all is well
Love Ann Rozansky
Completed

letterhead  File:Deerstalker hat, pipe lying on open book, lit candle, stack of books  THE CANDLELIGHT PRESS
PETER RUBER, Publisher  Editorial Offices:  430 East 86th Street, New York 28, N.Y., UNiversity 1-7733
December 3, 1963
Dear Jack: 

    Here is your copy of THREE LITERARY MEN which I promised you.   Do you think you might be able to review it in the underlined: Sun-Times ?  The U.S. book will be out in January.  I hope all goes well with you.

All Best.
Peter
Completed

Mr. Jack Conroy,

   I hope that my letter is reaching the proper Jack Conroy, Author of "The Disinherited"   The phone company out there gave me this Address.
   I am writing you a letter of thanx.  A Thankyou [sic] for your life and for The Disinherited.  I am not yet finished reading your Stories.  At the moment you are in Detroit working At the Badger Motor Co. on the assembly line.  I am reading Very slowly So as to Savor every moment of the excitement and moods you have put down in writing.  Your use of words and the vocabulary is Just grand to me.  I'm going to Copy every page to learn what I can from your Writing.
   I hope you'll let me Be a little more personal and Call  you Jack.  I'm an Actor and I'm from Kansas.  Salina Kansas to be exact.  I have my education and I now live in New York City.
Completed

Jack your Book will Be a Bible to me.  About people.  The real hard working people that make life in America.

   I'm 30 this January and come from a family where my father was a Truck Driver Coast to Coast.  The one thing I resent is that my growing-up has been Almost Apple-pie.  But I think that is what my parents wanted.  To not have their Children go Through What they did.  They gave me an Education along with life.
   But what your Book is teaching me is a value system.  Something my generation didn't get Because we were given everything.
   And what I am learning from your Book is Social Truth.
   And I feel every moment with the eyes you must have grasped it with.
Completed

Jack I may be in Kansas City around February.  And I would give a hell of a lot To just Shake your hand and Thanyou [sic] in person for this giant Work of Art.
   So much to say to you and I don't think I could get it all down on paper
   Jack if you have any ideas About what you see in the world Today and what you Think of Workers Today.  I would find it a gift from Heaven itself to hear your words.
   I want very much myself to carry on the Observations of the people you have written about in your Book.  A Thought from you that I could carry through my life To carry on some of the Work you've done, to keep it alive.  To keep the spirit of your writing Alive would Be wonderful.
  I know you are probably swamped with fan mail so I'll Just hope to hear from you.

Your Pal and Admiration
Veryle Rupp
Completed

P.S.

  I've enclosed a self-addressed Envelope Should you find time to let me know what your are up to.

And I hope you'll excuse me for Writing such a personal letter.
Completed

in pencil at top of page  Russell, Don (death, written by daughter)
April 15, 1986
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    It seems your name has been familiar to me as long as I can remember.
    When I brought Dad (and Mother) to Michigan to recover from bout in hospital with pneumonia I packed along "The Weed King & Other Stories" by Jack Conroy as I noticed a marker in the middle of it & knew he would be anxious to finish it.
    It was not to be.  On February 17th your old friend, Don Russell passed away.  
    Inside the book, the marker, your last letter to him, and so I have your address.  I am sorry I waited so long to write, but I have been busy running back & forth to Elmhurst tending to business & getting mother settled in -- as she doesn't want anyone living with her.
    By the way she is going to Cody, Wyoming in May accompanied
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Russell, Don - 15 Apr. 1986
by my sister, Martha Jane Bissell as they are going to have a memorial for my Dad out there.  They were going to honor him, and he had hoped to go.

   By the way I'm in the middle of your book right now and enjoying it immensely.  Of course, I remember the depression vividly & your account of your "adventures" in it while not like mine still brings back memories of not only the bad, but the way people made the best of it - and even - yes, laughed.
   Mother says she wants to read it when I'm through - and sentimental as I am I think I'll lay claim to it when she's through & I'll keep the marker & replace it inside.  So if you want your book reviewed I guess you'll have to send out another copy.
   My best to you.
   Sincerely, Elaine R. C. Jones

Mother's address is 191 Clinton - not 245 as you addressed it.  Elmhurst IL  60126
Completed

Sept. 2, 1970
Dear Mr. Conroy,

     I'm sure that you don't remember me, but I was at your home two years ago with St. Clair and Louise Kroese for part of an evening.
     Dave Perry told us that you would be willing to speak at our Folk University September 13.  Is that correct?   If so, would you write me please and tell me what your speech topic will be and at what time you would like to speak?   We have been having our meetings on Sundays at 2:00, but if another time would be
Completed

-2-
more convenient for you, we can change the time.  We would like to know all of this so that we can begin publicizing it.

    Could you also let me know when you expect to arrive so that we can prepare for you?
    Thank you so much.  We are all eagerly awaiting your visit.  I am particularly, since it has been so long since I've seen you.
    I await your answers.

Sincerely,
Jean Rust
Completed

Aug. 31, 1950
Dear Jack,

   And how are things at Yaddo?  Read in the Globe & heard from Nelson that you were up thar [sic], so decided to drop you a note.
    Things are popping on the crime front here.   Warden Chester L. Fardney is getting it in the neck regarding conditions at the County Jail & Boyle has demanded a grand jury investigation next month of the Whole thing.
    I've been working on a special report for the John Howard Association -
Completed

-2-
-- a private welfare prisoner's aid agency -- on "Prison Babies" -- a Study of Some Aspects of the Care & Treatment of Pregnant Inmates & Their Infants in Training Schools, Reformatories & Prisons.  It's an interesting study which ought to be helpful to institution heads, etc.

   Nelson introduced me to Bud Fallon (I had heard you & Nelson mention him several times before) last week.  He seems like an awfully nice guy.  We all went out to crossed out:  Irving  Arlington Park & all of us came out in the hole.  Lady Luck was not only
Completed

not with us, but she just sneered at us.

    Chicago, believe it or not, is really cool this summer.  Was in N.Y. the first part of June & was going to look up Chiye Mori who is also a friend of some friends, but time was short, so missed her.  She's with the East West Association doing research, I hear.   Bumped into Gigi & his wife Henrietta quite by accident in an Italian Restaurant right across from CBS. the last evening I was there.  They just live around the corner.
    Stud's Place was off for the summer but it will
Completed

be on again soon.  Did you by chance see Nelson when he was on the show?  He didn't do crossed out:  such a badly at all - in fact  he was quite good.  He missed his calling!   He wouldn't have received a "Tony", but it was surprisingly good.

    You heard the sad news of Thora, of course.  She used to be at the American Council on Race Relations when I was on the staff, & many of us thought she might have a break-down, but not so tragic as it happened.  Susie is Well-taken care of I understand by a couple.
    Well, this is about it.  Don't work too hard.  

Sincerely,
Mari
Completed

Wellfleet, Cape Cod, Mass.
Sept. 30, 1950
Dear Jack,

     It has been underlined:  extremely kind of you to send us your book.  It was forwarded to me from New York to the little house where I'm now living, with rabbits, foxes, bah and a Siamese cat which can talk German, twice the week, between 5 15 p.m. & 8 30 p.m.  I don't know how long I'm going to stay here, perhaps two more weeks or three - it is very lonely and already very cold during the night, and the last people with cars have left....
    I re-read the charming pieces by Eugene Field, and I remembered that night when you first red [sic] them to us, and Jane Mayhall was saying something about "the World is a Wedding, that's where we're heading; and we made the lifting-trick, and Mitsu sang a japanese lullabay [sic], and Philippe kept saying:  "!I don't agree with the United States ...!  It is a strange thing about Yaddo - when you are actually there
Completed

you are inclined to underestimate its advantages.  And soon after your departure it becomes a kind of paradise, An Intellectual Kindergarten, with free cereals, free Gin (if you know the right people) and office hours for poetry & abstract paintings (9 a.m to - 4 30 p.m.).

  It was wonderful to have met you there, Jack, and I'll try, indeed, to roll anybody's nose who should not agree with me that you are "a chic type" - as they say in France -, and I'll sock his head.   But it will be hard to find such a person.  We all were very fond of you, and I hope we will see each other again - in Yaddo, or New York, or Chicago.

So long, and thank you!
Ever yours
Hans Sahl
Completed

July 23, 1969
Dear Jack,

   I'm certainly not the best correspondent in this world, but, I do come out of the woodwork from time to time.   From time to time I hear of you through Dane Perry, who shows up in Kansas City from time to time.
   Are you still interested in holding forth on "Fiction and the Future of America",  "The Proleterian writer and Tomorrow", and "Proletarian Literature and Tomorrow"?  I give you these titles mostly by way of giving you a free rein on your talk or discussion.   In other words, take the problem "The Future of America" and relate it to your life and love.  I know the result will be good.
   August 20th would be a good day for your talk.  If you can't make it then, you might indicate other dates.  We can work the schedule around your time demands and problems.
   Of course, if you come down for the full two weeks, there'll be no problem!  How about it?

Sincerely yours,
handwritten addition at end of typed letter
The entire schedule will have to be changed or rearranged.  Pick any time, giving a two or three day Leeway if possible.

   Hope you can make it down.  If you want you may be able to ride with someone.  Rick Catlett intends to attend over weekends.
   You can reach me by this phone number:  753-8243.  Just tell the gal when you can come.

St Clair
Completed

spring meeting.  Its hard nowadays for me to get scholarly because of my play writing.  I'm finishing a farcical Western tragedy called "The Organ Grinder's Waltz" or Who says you can't get struck by a stray Bullet?"  Next I'm doing an anti-War play called "No," a heavy, straight drama, which I'm writing because its based on a powerful true story and because I want to establish to my candy-ass friends that I can write what they'll consider noble & precious before I return my dramas to the human race-with-clay-feet and my more lovable clowns.

   I don't mind the lack of  news coverage the fair day, however, I would like to see one of our plays bust out a hit on Broadway just so's I could see Giles Fowler hot foot it from his orfice [sic] in K.C. Star to the Foolkiller with socks sloshing full of his own shit!  It would have a dramatic touch to it.  But as per usual, it [sic] such blooming affairs, when you need you ain't got it & when you get it, you got too much.  Culture is perverse.
     Sounds like you're very productive these days.  Glad to hear it.

My best, Regards from all
St Clair
Completed

15 March 1975
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    Just a quick note to remind you that if all goes well, I'll be coming to Moberly on Saturday, the 22nd.   Ed Brand will be diving with me, and so, too, in all likelihood, will Ruth Pingozy.  Right now I'm fighting a flu (and not doing too well with it) but I'm hopeful that I'll be able to make the flight to St. Louis -- and then the drive to Moberly.
    Word is that a contract is being drawn up for a 2-volume Conroy Cornucopia.  Royalty will be 8% for you, with about a $500 advance upon submission of the manuscript.  If the contract is ready in time, I'll bring it with me (but don't count on its being ready.)  
    Hope to see you soon;  I'll call from St. Louis

Very best,
Jack Salze  Salzman

February 10, 1974
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   Thank you so much for your time and thought in reading my manuscript and writing to me.  This is a generous thing to do even for a close friend, let alone a stranger.   I would like to meet you sometime on one of my visits home to Ill. (Fairfield).
  underlined:  Blackberry Summer was true of course.  Dorothy is my older half-sister.  My mother died when I was seven and she was 29.  My sainted grandmother was my salvation.  Anyway, the story has been with a N.Y. firm since July & they have said "they'll work out something."  Maybe it will be hand carved in stone tablets (more nostalgia).
   I will send for your latest book.  I've had the Bontemps in the school lib. forever.  You should have had top billing.
   underlined:  Ruffles & Drums did well with ex-WACs who knew of it

3 ? Crescent
Sausalito, Cal.
Dec. 12   1948
Dear Jack:

   Your letter with the clippings of your reviews arrived just after I had mailed you my own latest communique.  The reviews were more than generous; - and I appreciate your help and support both in the press and with the book-sellers immensely.  Many thanks.
   Indeed it looks as if those of us who hope to write honestly about the world around us will have to figure out some sound and effective methods of mutual aid.  Certainly there is not much help forthcoming from the publishers, the book-sellers or the commercial reviewers - (with a few notable exceptions like your-
Completed

I have had no reports as yet from Appleton on the sales of the book.  Perhaps they don't know too much about it themselves until they hear from the bookstores.  So I shall await the year's end statement and hope for the best - for on that statement hangs the question of whether or not I can proceed immediately to the next book.
   Henceforth, I am going to advise all young aspiring writers to learn a trade the first thing they do - even before they buy a typewriter or look for an agent;  and I shall add that a good AFL building trade in some area where there is bad weather six months of the year would be a good bet.  I learned a trade - after a fashion at least - railroading.  But it turns out
Completed

to be a very difficult trade to combine with writing.  The difficulties are simple, but insurmountable:  when you are working, the hours are too long to leave any time for writing.  The pay is so low you can hardly support a family on it anyway.  And when you want to lay off for a while to write, you forfeit your seniority.  Then when you try to go back to work, you find - as I have just found - that there isn't a railroad job open in the whole state of California.  The trick would be to get a seasonal trade - or else one which a man can move in and out of under his own steam, like the building trades.  Too bad I didn't know all these details ten years ago.

   Do you know Nelson Algren's address?  I read his book underlined:  Never Come
Completed

underlined:  Morning some months ago and have been meaning to write him about it.  I found it a very moving and impressive book.

   Merry Christmas and greetings to your family.

Best regards
AI
Completed

Sunday Dec 23.
Dear Jack & Gladys.

    Thanks for the card and it was good to hear from you as always.  Yes - we do miss Sausalito & the Bay Area; and Los Angeles is hard to take sometimes.   We have just spent a week in Lone Pine - a little town on the east slope of the Sierra, under Mt. Whitney - a lovely area just between the desert & the mountain.  Still ?s...gless?,  though I don't know for how long  I'm delighted to hear about the anthology and sent in an order at once.  But which is the publisher - Lawrence Hill  - or ? Publishers Group? - I sent the order to Hill.  I will pass the brochures around.  Got a few more?  And when is publication date?  I will suggest reviewing it for the underlined:  Nation &/or underlined:  Labor History,  though it may already have been assigned by both those journals by    this time.  I will look to the chapter  in underlined:  Pop Culture.  Love to you both -  Trudy & Alex.

Dear Jack,

  Responding re underlined:  Labor History address - Bobst Library.  New York University, 70 Washington Square South, NY 10012.   Copy: $3.00; sub $10.00 (a quarterly).  Its about the size of underlined:  J of Pop Culture - and similarly academic, a trifle more so.  I didn't think Martin Savela "quit."  I thought (from what you wrote in underlined:  Rebel Voices ) that he was pushed out because publishers
Completed

didn't like what he was writing.

   One of my students - Maxine McCarty - is a great admirer of yours & is doing an essay on writers in '30's; she is romantic as well as intelligent & an avid reader & will enormously appreciate any aid you can give her.  She looked up Ashley Buck on her own out here & went to see him.
   On underlined:  Disinherited: the course will use 125 - 150 copies.  I will send you feedback on student response.  Meanwhile -- if you have time to send me a line or two of recollections of the circumstances of its germination, that would help me put it in context for readers under 25.  Best to you both - Alex.

File:Japanese painting of mountain and lake
Dec 8 1977.
Dear Jack & Gladys -

   Here's our best wishes for '78.  Delighted you got into the NEA for some $.  We were very sad to hear about the long haul Gladys has had - here's hoping for speedy recovery - and to be off cottage cheese & canned fruit - especially for Christmas.  Many thanks for December & the chapter of the autobiog - I'm looking forward to seeing these all together in a book.  Love & greetings from Lone Pine    Alex & Trudy
Completed

in pencil in top margin 1980   in pencil in right margin  Saxon [sic], Alex
Dear Jack & Gladys -

  Best wishes for the New Year to you both.  Things are going along about as usual for us.  We were in Lone Pine (sabbatical quarter) through the autumn;  back to LA for winter quarter.  Our new LA address:  2405 Roscomare Rd #5 LA Cal 90024  Love to you both, Trudy & Alex
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Saxton,  Alex and Trudy
October 19, 1989
Dear Jack & Carolee -

    Good to hear from you and thanks for writing.   We are hanging in as well as we can.   Trudy has had a long hard time with a broken ankle for which, after many months of physical therapy, she has had to go back for another round of surgery.  And we have both had cataract implants, but are seeing quite well as a result.  This part of California is still beautiful and there are still places that look like the picture on the other side.  Trudy and I have been reading the recent biography of James Baldwin; and there is a biography of Paul Robeson that is supposed - by the reviews - to be very good.  Things are changing - a underlined: little bit!   There is a man at Michigan (sorry, I can't think of  his name, although I met him last spring) who is working on a revisionist study of the "proletarian" novelists.  He is doing very detailed research and is approaching them much more seriously than the previous rather stereotyped studies.

Our love & best wishes to both -- Alex & Trudy Saxton.
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Saxton, Alex
greeting card  Peace, joy and friendship    Paix, joie et amitié     Paz, júbilo y amistad     Slavic characters, Chinese characters
1
Dec      15 1959
Dear Carolee & Jack -

    Thank you for the good letter.  I have not had a chance to answer till now because we have had a hassle with our water pipes.  We had to put in a new well and I was rushing around trying to get the pipes hooked up & insulated before the freezing weather started.  This [[underlined: is] a desert area and it can get very hot, even in winter, in day time.  But it can also drop way below freezing, especially in December-January.  We have had beautiful weather this fall, but that is not all to the good, since we are now in the 4th year of unusual dry seasons, and the whole eastern side of the high Sierra is desperately in need of snow.  (continued on  post cards --
Completed

postcard  BODIE STATE HISTORIC PARK   Named after Waterman S. Body who discovered gold her in 1859, Bodie soon boasted a population of more than 10,000, its bad men and wicked climate justified a schoolgirls statement, "Goodbye God.  I'm going to Bodie."
2
our cataract surgeries all turned out well, and we are seeing better than for several years past.  Trudy continues to have a bad time with complications from her broken ankle, and she is back in the hospital now for several days as they try to speed the healing.  We did not feel the earthquake here at Lone Pine, but our daughters were shaken considerably.
Completed

postcard  NORTH LAKE   Basking in the sun's early light, the rugged Sierra Nevada is reflected in the calm waters of North Lake.  the popular fishing spot is a reservoir on the North Fork of Bishop Creek.

3
One lives ins SF, the other in Santa Cruz.  They did not suffer injuries or damage, but both were without electricity for a day or more, and the one in Santa Cruz, without water for a while.  Santa Cruz & Watsonville both suffered heavy damage that has not gotten much media attention.  As the underlined:  Nation commented, Watsonville is a "third world" working class town, and the media have been much more interested in "first world" yuppie communities like
Completed
File:Lake reflecting a range of mountains and blue sky
Completed

4
the Marina in SF.  Both our daughters will be here at Christmas which I am glad of especially since it will cheer Trudy up, who has had a very hard year.

    I am on half-time this year and will be teaching only in spring quarter.  After that I will be fully retired.   I have been working on some projects with a man I am sure you know - David Roediger at U of Missouri, Columbia.   He edited the underlined:  Haymarket Reader several years ago, and he & several others were seeking to reconstitute the old Kerr publishing house in Chicago.  I don't know whether or not that effort has proved successful.
   Just a note on the two post cards:  Bodie is one of the best preserved Mark Twain type mine
Completed

camps in the Far West.  It began producing silver in the 1860s , reached its heyday about 1890. and had a bit of a revival in the 1930s when FDR put the US on silver coinage again.  Much of it has burned, but many buildings still remain, including a theater and the old Miners' Union hall.   Bodie is now a state monument.  North Lake is about 9000 ft high,  right above Bishop.  We used to go there to start back-packing vacations when our daughters were 8 & 11.

   Our love & very best wishes to you both -

Trudy & Alex Saxton
